3.text: - So we know that starting a company

6.text: or being involved with a start-up

8.text: is full of surprises and often

11.text: pits that you fall into, as well as really fabulous highs.

16.text: Have there been already some surprises

19.text: that you could share with us?

21.text: Obviously you started with the idea

22.text: that okay, this is gonna be fabulous and great,

25.text: but what happened that might have

28.text: Cody, do you want to start?

30.text: - Yeah, for us, we're surprised that,

31.text: so we built a training tool for professional athletes

33.text: to use VR to train, and we're always surprised

36.text: that coaches don't want to use the tool.

38.text: I think the biggest surprise for me is

41.text: how important sales is to our cycle,

43.text: is to actually try to sell this tool,

46.text: because to us we are a company of athletes

48.text: and sports-minded folk, but the sales process

52.text: is so important to the industry,

55.text: and I think the biggest surprise was just

56.text: how hard we need to work at that.

59.text: So instead of proving it as a tool,

61.text: it's always about pitching it to kind of,

63.text: how do they use it in a way that is effective for them,

69.text: and how do we pitch it to them as something that's gonna be

71.text: non-invasive to their current coaching philosophies.

75.text: if we built it, they will come.

78.text: that that was certainly not the case.

80.text: - It's not the case yeah, so we're still working on that.

85.text: I think generally speaking, the genomics industry

89.text: and the technology that's been developing over the last

92.text: decade has been moving extraordinarily quickly.

94.text: The cost per sequencing a base pair

97.text: is dropping much much faster than Moore's Law,

101.text: exponentially faster, in fact, and so it's really enabled

105.text: this technology to be applied in a clinical setting

108.text: now very rapidly, so I think at a meta level

110.text: that's been a surprise to all of us

112.text: in terms of how quickly that technology has developed.

115.text: But I think for us at the start-up,

119.text: and so the rate at which we've been growing,

121.text: we have a company value of GSD, which is Get Stuff Done.

127.text: It's just been a phenomenal experience

130.text: over the last several months to see how much a group

133.text: of really smart, like-minded, mission-driven folks

136.text: can get done, and so as an example,

138.text: we brought in our first wave of hires in March

141.text: and by August we had already started

143.text: enrolling in our first clinical trial,

146.text: which will end up enrolling over 10,000 subjects.

149.text: And just the pace at which that has happened

152.text: is pretty unprecedented in the oncology space.

156.text: And so that's been a very pleasing surprise for all of us.

159.text: - [Woman On Left] Great, so a good surprise.

163.text: - Yeah, I think for me, the big surprise was

167.text: when we were first starting this and kind of

169.text: working in the evenings, figuring things out,

172.text: I sort of naively thought that, oh,

177.text: we have two technical founders and one business co-founder,

181.text: and someone will give us an initial amount of money

184.text: to get out there and get going,

186.text: and then the later stage funding would be the hard part,

189.text: the first funding would be really easy.

192.text: And that turned out to not be the case at all.

194.text: No one really wanted to give us any money 'cause we had

196.text: no prototype, we just had an idea and had a decent story.

201.text: So what we had to do was end up getting government

204.text: funding to build our initial prototype,

206.text: and in general we've had to diversify

208.text: the streams in which we've raised money.

210.text: So we've also looked at philanthropy and family offices

213.text: and kind of to get us to the stage

216.text: where we would be attractive to venture funding

218.text: at a later point, we're still not there yet.

220.text: We're bringing in angel investors and that type of thing,

223.text: but we're not quite ready for the venture capital funding.

226.text: And so that has been the most surprising part,

228.text: you hear all these stories about, oh,

230.text: a couple students got their initial seed funding

232.text: right out of school and then could take off.

234.text: For a clean tech company, and doing hardware,

241.text: - So, I was surprised by how many people

244.text: will tell you that you can't do it.

247.text: When I started Bright, so, I wasn't fluent in Spanish,

251.text: I still am not, and our first market is Mexico.

253.text: So there were some things that just didn't make sense,

255.text: and I knew that, but I also was very surprised

258.text: that so many people said, that just doesn't make sense,

260.text: you can't start in a country you've never been to

263.text: that you have no connections to,

265.text: and you can't speak the language.

267.text: And it was like, the nos, and, what are you doing,

270.text: you're crazy, would come from everywhere.

272.text: I think there was maybe 5% of the people I talked to

275.text: that were really supportive, and like, this is a great idea.

278.text: But it's kind of like, I don't know if anyone,

280.text: who here has signed up for a race

283.text: that they thought was a crazy race,

285.text: but then because they signed up, they just did it?

288.text: That's how it works, and it's kind of the same

292.text: You kind of just have to sign up, make the leap,

295.text: and then on the opposite side of the coin,

298.text: I was surprised by how much you can

299.text: figure out if you just do that.

301.text: Actually, I flew to Mexico for the first time

306.text: and the power of the Stanford network,

308.text: I reached out to Stanford alumni in Mexico,

310.text: and someone I had never met, I ended up staying with,

313.text: and my flight was late, so I ended up

315.text: getting there at midnight, he was asleep.

317.text: It was a very awkward interaction when I was blowing up

319.text: the air mattress to sleep on his floor.

321.text: And that's, it's a crazy start,

323.text: but that was my first connection in Mexico,

325.text: and then it just grew from there.

327.text: And yeah, it was crazy and it didn't make any sense.

329.text: But kind of signing up for it is the most important step

332.text: that you can take, and you'll test your limits,

335.text: but you will succeed far more

337.text: than you think you're capable of,

339.text: and it will only happen if you sign up.
